Description: Fragment of a small seal-impression made of fine brown Nile clay that was hardened after excavation and shows darker discolouration with a partly glossy surface. The rear shows a surface that is bent almost by 90 degrees like from a leather bag and perpendicular to this three impressions of a thin turned cord with a width of 0.1-0.2 cm in the break. The front has a small flat area, the lateral sides bend downwards. On the flat part the upper half of an oval scarab-like seal-impression is preserved, showing the god Ptah in mummy-form in the middle, facing towards the left, holding a wAs-sceptre in front of him. Small hieroglyphs above this figure, nb ... (qnb.t?) . In front of him another sign, maybe two Dd-pillars with each a seated falcon on top (?). Behind the god another standing figure, maybe Sekhmet, with a sceptre in front of her, above a sun-disc. The rest is broken off. Same motif on EA86900.
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
